dialogueTree.text: The machine is dead and silent. It needs serious maintenance before anyone can play again.

links.text: The pinball machine?
Not just any pinball machine. This is the pinnacle of pinball. 'Cornelius Gurdi and the Mountain Goats'. It's lit. You can't wait to get your hands on it.
'Lit' - a phrase almost synonymous with the Insulindian pinball scene. *Any* pinball scene really.
"Check it out, Cuno." (Point to the machine.)
"Fuck does Cuno care," he asks, glancing at the machine. "Cuno doesn't fucking care."
"Kim, are you seeing what I'm seeing?" (Point to the machine.)
"The pinball machine?" The lieutenant glances at the machine. "Gurdi's Goats. A classic."
Oh it's more than just a classic -- a must-play. All serious pinballers have attempted a *tempo-run*.
The Greats like Gottwald's Knut Schmelling and Jörgen Stirneman, Mesque pinball legend Iara Flávia Jandiroba and Zsiemsk-born phenom, Ludek Smolka, have all managed a sub-twenty minute run.
"Wait, you've played it?"
"A little."
Feels like a *lot*. Too much to play it again.
"Let's take a closer look." (Pull out the machine.)
"Oh, great." The lieutenant sighs.
'CORNELIUS GURDI AND THE MOUNTAIN GOATS' reads the golden lettering on top of the backbox. There's a small column of text underneath it. The machine is coin-operated.
Get the game on, finger-boy! Those flippers are *ready*.
Lean closer to read the text.

Above the painting of a moustached man climbing a hill, a column reads: 'Inspired by the legend of Cornelius Gurdi taking on the world's tallest peak, Corpus Mundi. The Mesque legends holds that when the nation is in danger, heroic Gurdi shall return and save his people.
Corpus Mundi, the dormant shield volcano on the Mundi isola is indeed the highest peak in the known world. At the height of 18.9 km it almost reaches stratosphere.
Inspect the playing field.
The theme of the game is to explore Gurdi’s climb through the perspective of goats, and to ascend to the top of the mountain in a time of trouble.
The peak of the mountain is at the top of the playfield. All the balls have small goat icons on them, and represent the goats as they race up and down the mountain.
Areas around the playfield represent Gurdi’s climb: Places he was said to have camped, which the goats can discover. Get them to the summit!
What's with all the goats?

Mesque culture holds a special place for the mountain goat, especially those on Corpus Mundi -- the only creature fearless and agile enough to climb the mountain. They are often associated with Gurdi.
Indeed. Think of them as balls.
And Gurdi?

Cornelius Gurdi was a Mesque mountaineer, travel-writer and a national hero, known for his daring expeditions into the far corners of the world and perhaps even more daring statements in the public arena. He never returned from his final conquest -- Corpus Mundi.
Despite the colorful images on the backglass, there's definitely something sinister about the guy.
A mountaineer? A Mesque nationalist? A goat herd? Play the damn game already.
Insert coin.
It takes a while to get into a rhythm, but pretty soon you're able to keep three goat-faced balls in play with with relative ease.
Go-go, finger-boy!
"I feel sorry for the goats. If they only knew the kind of guy old Cornelius really was..."
"Wait, what 'kind of guy' was he then?"
"The kind of a guy who uses the word 'savages' a lot when recounting his travels. A Mesque nationalist."
"A racist mountaineer?"
"An avid huntsman too," the lieutenant adds. "He was often photographed in his dining hall, surrounded by wall-mounted hunting trophies from every continent."
"That is *not* cool."
"He also hit his wife. And kids. Other people's kids too. Sometimes pets. Hateful little man."
*That's* what they should've turned into a pinball game.
"But you seem to be having fun?" He nods at the machine.
"Technically the human beings *are* at the top of the food-chain, so..."
"I'm pretty good at this." (Continue playing.)
Your game is definitely improving. The jolly goats are flying all over the board and although a few plummet to their deaths you're never left with less than three.
Natural selection.
Suddenly a special passage, leading to the summit, slides open at the top of the board. This is where the balls need to go.
Concentrate and aim for the narrow  passage.
Maneuvering a goat-ball into a position for a perfect hit isn't easy. More fall to their deaths, but finally the opportunity presents itself. One of them gets through.
Tiny hammer shatters something inside the machine. Something glass.
An ampoule?
The last one.
The words 'PALE RUPTURE' light up on the speaker panel and the machine starts filling with a thick milky fog... something's happening.
"Congratulations." The lieutentant nods. "This is where the game ends. It's a cheap way of getting more money out of the players. A stupid, nihilistic finale."
There's so much fog you can barely see anything. Some is actually leaking out of the machine and one by one your goats start slipping, disappearing into the milky nothingness.
Lucky goats. The fog looks soft and inviting.
This *can* be navigated. The balls leave an almost imperceptible 'disruptions' in the fog. Use them to calculate where they hit next.
Hit the pads as fast as you can, maximum attack -- not even a bullet can get through!
The amount of focus it takes to predict when a ball-goat is in striking range is staggering, but it *can* be done. Focus!
You're down to your last goat, going mostly by sound -- eyes are useless at this point -- but that goat is something special. Five times you snatch him back from the jaws of death.
You're in a perfectly balanced system, where neither you nor the pale is able to get the upper hand. This could go on forever.
"Cuno, I'm killing it -- watch me play!"
The kid doesn't reply. He's squinting, eyes desperately trying to pierce the relentless fog.
"Kim, it can be done -- just watch!"
"I am. I've seen it before. Played it too. You will eventually make a mistake -- and then it's all over."
Only the tension in his posture betrays his interest.
Stay on the ball.
With automaton-like precision you keep the final goat-ball in play, reacting to the tiniest stimuli, floating in the flow state. The fog is clearing and suddenly the old speaker crackles:
"GURDI-BALL IS LIT!"
"Huh?"
A panel opens at the top of the playfield and a new ball charges downhill. It's larger than the goats and matte black. 'CORNELIUS' spell the white letters running across the equator.
So violent is it's descent it immediately knocks the last goat into the abyss, then proceeds to bounce all across the board as if carried by some demonic other-wordly inertia.

'HIGH SCORE,' announce the speakers and the whole machine lights up. Then the flippers retract, leaving a perfect opening for the Gurdi-ball to join the goats backstage. 'Cornelius' vanishes and the machine powers off.
"That's amazing," the lieutenant mumbles. He sounds a little out of breath.
"I think I won, Kim."
"You didn't just win. *No one* I know has ever beaten Gurdi's Goats. That is a monumental achievement, detective."
“Wait, but what about Smolka, Jandiroba, Stirneman, and Schmelling?”
“Those are professional tempo runners. They’re paid four figures *per* game. I meant normal human beings.”
"Who's the king of pinball, Kim." (Hold out your fist.)
"Congratulations, your highness," the lieutenant replies. His knuckles touch yours and he smiles. "That was really impressive."
"The machine needs a good service before anyone else can even attempt it again."
"It's just a silly game, lieutenant."
"Of course." He nods. "I still think you earned the right to be at least a little proud."
"Cuno, did you see that? I got the high score."
"Shit that's tense," mumbles the kid, eyes still on the lifeless machine. He quickly gathers himself and adds:
"Whatever. Cuno doesn't give a shit."
Pig's got mad timing. Fast-twitch fiber shit, interceptor shit. Animal instinct-style.
Did I... win?
You didn't *just* win, you absolute legend, you joined a very exclusive club of people who've ever achieved this monumental feat.
Too bad no one was around to witness your triumph. It was a 'high score' after all.
"It's time to move on." [Leave.]
"Yes." The lieutenant gives 'CORNELIUS GURDI AND THE MOUNTAIN GOATS' one last look. "Good times."
Once again the machine becomes one with the dust and the darkness.
Life has left it, unlikely to ever return.
How, if you can't even see it?
The last goat plummets into the fog with almost suicidal glee.
It killed himself to *spite* you.
"Why do they even make these if it's impossible to win?!" [Give up, winning is too stressful.]
"Mhmh, I've been wondering the same."
There goes nothing, finger-boy.
The kid shrugs, clearly relieved to get going.
"The fuck?"
"Enough with the fun." [Leave.]
The kid on your side looks bored. The game doesn't speak to him.
If he's off the speed-train there isn't much that 'speaks to him'. At least for few days.
"Pinball isn't for me." [Leave.]
The kid shrugs. He doesn't care.
No, I'm out. [Leave.]
Ignore the machine.
